title: 103_hr3267
content:
The "Full Employment Act for Fiscal Year 1994" provides supplemental appropriations for various agencies including the Department of Agriculture for watershed and flood prevention operations, and the Rural Development Administration for rural water and waste disposal grants. The "Full Employment Act for Fiscal Year 1994" provides additional funding for rural water and waste disposal grants, the special supplemental food program for women, infants, and children (WIC), and the Small Business Administration's business loans program account. The Department of the Interior's National Park Service is allocated $146.5 million for the operation of the national park system and $83.6 million for construction. The Department of Agriculture's Forest Service receives $150 million for the national forest system for maintenance, repairs, and conservation activities, as well as $37.8 million for recreation facility and trail construction. The Department of Energy focuses on energy conservation efforts. The Department of Energy allocates $100,800,000 for enhanced energy conservation activities. The Department of Labor receives $1,000,000,000 for training and employment services under the Job Training Partnership Act. Additionally, $19,100,000 is allocated for community service employment for older Americans under the Department of Labor. The Department of Health and Human Services receives funding for health resources and services administration. The curr_chunk provides additional funding for various programs:
- $170,000,000 for health services under the Public Health Service Act
- $300,000,000 for childhood immunization activities
- $500,000,000 for the Head Start Act
- $500,000,000 for compensatory education grants under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The curr_chunk provides $1,521,700,000 for student financial assistance under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Additionally, $500,000,000 is allocated for airport grants-in-aid and $500,000,000 for federal-aid highways under the Federal Highway Administration. For Federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs, $2,976,000,000 from the Highway Trust Fund. Federal Railroad Administration receives $187,800,000 for capital improvements grants. Federal Transit Administration gets $466,500,000 for formula grants. Internal Revenue Service allocated funds for information systems. The Internal Revenue Service is allocated $148,400,000 for information systems. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives $423,000,000 for the transitional and supportive housing demonstration program, and $2,536,000,000 for community development grants. The Environmental Protection Agency also receives funding. The Environmental Protection Agency is allocated $845,300,000 for state revolving funds/construction grants under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to change overtime pay from one and a half times to two times and reduce the standard workweek from forty hours to thirty hours. Section 7 of the Act is also amended to adjust various hourly thresholds for overtime pay. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to reduce the standard workweek from forty hours to thirty hours and adjust various hourly thresholds for overtime pay. Section 13 of the Act is amended to change the maximum hours from fifty-six to forty-five. The amendments made by section 201 of the Act will take effect 180 days after enactment. Section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to set the minimum wage at $7.00 an hour. This change will also take effect 180 days after the Act is enacted. Tax incentives for businesses that hire new employees, create jobs, provide education and training, child care, health care plans, and undertake research and development are recommended by Congress. Individuals receiving assistance from Federal entitlement programs should aim to secure employment with livable wages and affordable child care arrangements, according to Congress.
